verses.arabic: وَمِنْهُم مَّن يَقُولُ رَبَّنَآ ءَاتِنَا فِى ٱلدُّنْيَا حَسَنَةً وَفِى ٱلْـَٔاخِرَةِ حَسَنَةً وَقِنَا عَذَابَ ٱلنَّارِ
verses.transliteration: Wa-minhum man yaqūlu rabbanā ātinā fī l-dunyā ḥasanatan wa-fī l-ākhirati ḥasanatan wa-qinā ʿadhāba l-nāri
verses.translation: Yet there are others who say, 'Our Lord! Grant us the good of this world and the Hereafter, and protect us from the torment of the Fire.'

grammar.function: Connects this sentence to the previous verse
grammar.reason: Links the description of different types of people - contrasting those who only ask for worldly things with those mentioned in this verse who seek both worlds.
grammar.practical: The connecting word 'and'. It transitions from the previous verse about people who only ask for this world, to NOW describe a better group - those who ask for good in both worlds. This 'wa' shows contrast: 'but among them...'

grammar.reason: Specifies that this group is FROM AMONG the people mentioned before. The 'hum' refers back to mankind in general.
grammar.practical: 'Min' means 'from' and 'hum' means 'them', so 'minhum' = 'from among them'. This introduces a subset of people - not all people are like this, but SOME among them have this beautiful quality. When you see 'min + pronoun', it means 'from/among that group'.

grammar.function: Introduces an indefinite person or group
grammar.reason: Used to describe an unspecified group of people. 'Man' here means 'whoever' or 'those who' - not naming them specifically but describing their qualities.
grammar.practical: This word means 'who' or 'those who' when referring to people in a general, non-specific way. Together with 'minhum', it creates 'among them are those who...'. This opens the description of what these people DO - which comes in the next verb.

grammar.reason: Describes the ongoing or habitual action of saying/supplicating. Though referring to a group, Arabic often uses singular form with 'man' for elegance.
grammar.practical: From the root 'qāla' (to say). The 'ya-' prefix makes it present tense: 'he says' or 'they say'. The '-u' ending indicates it's singular masculine present. This describes what these people habitually SAY in their prayers - their characteristic supplication. Present tense shows this is their regular practice.

grammar.root: ر-ب-ب (r-b-b) - to nurture, to sustain, to be lord
grammar.reason: The beginning of their supplication. 'Rabb' means Lord/Master/Sustainer, and 'nā' makes it 'our Lord'. This is how believers address Allah in prayer.
grammar.practical: Beautiful word meaning 'Our Lord'! 'Rabb' isn't just 'lord' - it means the One who creates, sustains, nourishes, and manages all affairs. The 'nā' at the end makes it possessive: OUR Lord. Notice how the supplication starts - not jumping straight to requests, but first recognizing WHO they're calling upon. This teaches us prayer etiquette - start by addressing Allah with His beautiful attributes.

grammar.root: أ-ت-ي (a-t-y) - to come, to bring, to give
grammar.person: Second person imperative with first person plural object
grammar.reason: This is a respectful request/supplication to Allah. Though grammatically imperative, when addressing Allah it's understood as humble supplication, not a command.
grammar.practical: Means 'give us' or 'grant us'. The root 'atā' means to give/bring. In Form IV, it becomes 'ātā' (to grant/bestow). The 'nā' at the end means 'us', so 'ātinā' = 'grant us'. This is the imperative/request form. Note: when we use command forms with Allah, it's not commanding Him - it's a humble, urgent request, like a child earnestly asking a parent.

grammar.reason: Shows WHERE they want goodness - specifically IN this world. The preposition 'fī' indicates the domain or realm.
grammar.practical: Simple preposition meaning 'in'. It specifies the location or realm where they're seeking goodness. Here it means 'IN this world' - during our worldly life. This 'fī' makes the word after it take kasrah (i ending).

grammar.root: د-ن-و (d-n-w) - to be near, to be lower
grammar.reason: Refers to this present, worldly life. Called 'dunyā' (from 'danā' - near) because it's the nearer/closer life compared to the afterlife. The genitive case is due to the preposition 'fī'.
grammar.practical: Means 'the world' or 'this worldly life'. From root 'd-n-w' meaning 'near/lower' - this life is called 'dunyā' because it's the NEARER one (we're in it now) and LOWER in value compared to the eternal hereafter. Notice it ends in 'ā' sound - this is a special feminine ending. It's in genitive case (conceptually 'i' but written as 'ā' because of the special ending) due to coming after the preposition 'fī'.

grammar.root: ح-س-ن (ḥ-s-n) - to be good, beautiful, excellent
grammar.reason: This is the object of 'ātinā' - WHAT they're requesting. Accusative case because it's the direct object. The indefinite form with tanwīn suggests vastness and magnificence.
grammar.practical: Means 'goodness' or 'good things'. From the root 'ḥasana' (to be good/beautiful). The '-atan' ending shows it's: 1) feminine, 2) accusative case (it's WHAT they want granted), and 3) indefinite with tanwīn. That tanwīn (-an sound) makes it general and magnificent: not just 'a good thing' but ANY and ALL goodness! Beautiful: they're asking for COMPLETE goodness in this world - health, sustenance, knowledge, family, peace, everything good!
Links the request for worldly good with the request for goodness in the hereafter. Shows these believers want BOTH - they don't neglect either world!
Same preposition 'in', now specifying the hereafter as the realm.

grammar.root: أ-خ-ر (a-kh-r) - to be last, to come after
grammar.case: Genitive (majrūr) - ends in kasrah (i) due to 'fī'
grammar.reason: Refers to the life after death, the eternal life. Called 'ākhirah' (from 'ākhir' - last/final) because it comes after this life and is the final, eternal destination.
grammar.practical: Means 'the Hereafter' or 'the Next Life'. From root 'ākhara' (to be last/final). This is the FINAL life, the eternal one after death. The 'i' ending shows it's in genitive case because of the preposition 'fī'. Notice the beautiful balance: these believers ask for good IN THIS WORLD (dunyā) AND IN THE NEXT WORLD (ākhirah) - they're balanced, not obsessed with only one!

grammar.reason: Same as before - the object of what they request for the hereafter. The repetition emphasizes they want goodness in BOTH realms.
grammar.practical: Same word as before - 'goodness'. The repetition is intentional and beautiful: they want ḥasanah (complete goodness) in dunyā AND ḥasanah in ākhirah! This balanced supplication shows wisdom - not neglecting either world. In the hereafter, this 'ḥasanah' means Paradise, Allah's pleasure, high ranks, seeing Allah's face!
Adds the third part of this comprehensive supplication - protection from evil.

words.translation: protect us / guard us / save us

grammar.root: و-ق-ي (w-q-y) - to protect, to guard, to shield
grammar.person: Second person imperative with first person plural object
grammar.reason: Request for protection from Allah. The root w-q-y means to protect/shield - same root as 'taqwā' (God-consciousness/protection from sin).
grammar.practical: Beautiful word meaning 'protect us' or 'save us'! From the root 'waqā' (to protect/shield) - same root as 'taqwā'! The imperative form 'qi' means 'protect', and 'nā' means 'us'. So 'qinā' = 'protect us'. Notice how comprehensive this prayer is: Grant us good in both worlds AND protect us from evil! This is the third element of a complete supplication.

grammar.reason: The direct object of 'qinā' - WHAT they want protection from. Accusative because it's the object of the verb.
grammar.practical: Means 'punishment' or 'torment'. From root 'ʿadhaba' (to punish). The 'a' ending (fatha) shows it's accusative - it's WHAT they want protection FROM. But this word is in construct form (iḍāfah), so it connects to the next word to specify WHICH punishment...

grammar.type: Ism - Noun in Genitive Construction (Muḍāf ilayhi)
grammar.root: ن-و-ر (n-w-r) - to burn, to be fire
grammar.case: Genitive (majrūr) - ends in kasrah (i) due to iḍāfah
grammar.reason: Specifies WHICH punishment - the punishment OF the Fire. In genitive case because it's the second part of the construct (iḍāfah) phrase 'ʿadhāb al-nār' (punishment of the Fire).
grammar.practical: Means 'the Fire' - referring to Hellfire. The 'i' ending shows genitive case because it comes after 'ʿadhāb' in a possessive construction: 'punishment OF the Fire'. Together: 'protect us from the punishment of the Fire'. This completes the balanced supplication: grant us good in both worlds AND save us from the worst evil - Hellfire. This single verse (2:201) is considered one of the most comprehensive, balanced prayers in the Quran!

verses.arabic: أُو۟لَـٰٓئِكَ لَهُمْ نَصِيبٌ مِّمَّا كَسَبُوا۟ ۚ وَٱللَّهُ سَرِيعُ ٱلْحِسَابِ
verses.transliteration: Ulāika lahum naṣībun mimmā kasabū wal-lahu sarīʿu l-ḥisābi
verses.translation: Those will receive a share of what they earned. Allah is swift in accounting.

grammar.reason: Points to the people described in the previous verse - those who make the balanced supplication. The distant demonstrative shows their elevated status.
grammar.practical: Means 'those people' or 'these people'. This is the PLURAL form of demonstratives, pointing to a group. Specifically refers to the believers mentioned in verse 201 who ask for good in both worlds. The 'ka' at the end adds emphasis and distance, showing respect and honor. When Quran says 'ulāika' about someone, it's highlighting their special status!

grammar.reason: Shows that something belongs to them or is for their benefit. The 'la' indicates possession, 'hum' refers to the people mentioned.
grammar.practical: 'La' means 'for' or 'to', and 'hum' means 'them'. Together: 'for them' or 'they have'. This construction in Arabic expresses possession: THEY HAVE (something). This introduces what Allah will give them as a result of their beautiful, balanced supplication.

words.translation: a share / a portion / a reward

grammar.root: ن-ص-ب (n-ṣ-b) - to appoint, to assign a portion
grammar.case: Nominative (marfūʿ) - indicated by ḍammah with tanwīn (-un)
grammar.reason: This is what they will receive - their share or portion of reward. Nominative case as the subject. The tanwīn suggests magnificence - a GREAT share!
grammar.practical: Means 'a share' or 'a portion'. From the root 'naṣaba' (to assign/appoint). The '-un' ending shows: 1) nominative case (it's the subject of the sentence), and 2) indefinite tanwīn. That tanwīn is beautiful - it makes it indefinite and magnificent: not just 'a small share' but a TREMENDOUS portion! These believers will have a GREAT share of reward!

grammar.reason: These merge to form 'mimmā'. Introduces the source of their reward - FROM WHAT they earned.
grammar.practical: Combination of 'min' (from) + 'mā' (what) = 'mimmā' (from what). The double 'mm' shows the merging. This specifies the SOURCE of their reward - it's from WHAT they did. It introduces the explanation of where this 'naṣīb' (share) comes from.

grammar.root: ك-س-ب (k-s-b) - to earn, to acquire, to gain
grammar.reason: Describes what they did - their actions/deeds. The plural 'ū' ending indicates 'they earned'. Past tense indicates completed deeds.
grammar.practical: Means 'they earned' or 'they acquired'. From root 'kasaba' (to earn/gain). The '-ū' ending is the signature of 'they' in past tense. So 'kasabū' = 'they earned'. This beautiful word shows that good deeds are EARNINGS - investments that bring returns! Their share is FROM WHAT THEY EARNED - meaning their good deeds, their balanced prayers, their good works are all recorded and will be rewarded!
Connects the promise of reward with a statement about Allah's nature.

grammar.reason: The subject of this sentence. Allah is described by what follows. Nominative case as the subject.
grammar.practical: Allah - the name of God in Arabic. The 'u' ending shows it's in nominative case - it's the subject of the sentence (who we're talking about). What follows will describe Allah's attribute.

grammar.root: س-ر-ع (s-r-ʿ) - to be swift, to be quick
grammar.reason: Describes Allah's attribute of being swift. The 'faʿīl' pattern emphasizes the intensity of the quality. In construct form with what follows.
grammar.practical: Means 'swift' or 'quick'. From root 'saraʿa' (to be fast). The pattern 'faʿīl' (like sarīʿ) indicates an intense, permanent quality - VERY swift! This is the first part of a construct phrase (will connect to next word). The 'u' ending would normally be there but is dropped in pronunciation due to the construct state.

grammar.type: Ism - Noun in Genitive Construction (Muḍāf ilayhi)
grammar.root: ح-س-ب (ḥ-s-b) - to calculate, to reckon, to account
grammar.case: Genitive (majrūr) - ends in kasrah (i) due to iḍāfah
grammar.reason: Completes the construct phrase 'sarīʿu l-ḥisāb' (swift in reckoning). Genitive case as the second part of iḍāfah.
grammar.practical: Means 'the reckoning' or 'the accounting'. From root 'ḥasaba' (to calculate/count). The 'i' ending shows genitive case because it completes the construct phrase: 'sarīʿu l-ḥisāb' = 'Swift in Reckoning'. Together this means Allah is quick to take account of deeds - He doesn't forget anything, and He rewards/punishes swiftly. This is both a promise (quick reward for good) and a warning (quick accountability for evil). Beautiful ending reminding us: your deeds are being recorded, and Allah's accounting is swift!

verses.arabic: وَٱذْكُرُوا۟ ٱللَّهَ فِىٓ أَيَّامٍ مَّعْدُودَٰتٍۢ ۚ فَمَن تَعَجَّلَ فِى يَوْمَيْنِ فَلَآ إِثْمَ عَلَيْهِ وَمَن تَأَخَّرَ فَلَآ إِثْمَ عَلَيْهِ ۚ لِمَنِ ٱتَّقَىٰ ۗ وَٱتَّقُوا۟ ٱللَّهَ وَٱعْلَمُوٓا۟ أَنَّكُمْ إِلَيْهِ تُحْشَرُونَ
verses.transliteration: Wa-udhkurū l-laha fī ayyāmin maʿdūdātin faman taʿajjala fī yawmayni falā ithma ʿalayhi waman taakhkhara falā ithma ʿalayhi limani ttaqā wa-ttaqū l-laha wa-iʿlamū annakum ilayhi tuḥsharūn
verses.translation: And remember Allah during appointed days. Whoever departs swiftly on the second day is not sinful, neither are those who stay behind till the third, so long as they are mindful. And be mindful of Allah, and know that to Him you will all be gathered.

grammar.practical: Connects to previous verses, introducing new guidance about remembering Allah during Hajj.

grammar.root: ذ-ك-ر (dh-k-r) - to remember, to mention, to commemorate
grammar.reason: Direct command to the believers to remember Allah. The plural 'ū' ending addresses the entire community.
grammar.practical: Command form meaning 'Remember!' or 'Mention!'. From root 'dhakara' (to remember). The '-ū' ending makes it plural: 'You all remember!' This is a direct command from Allah to remember Him. Dhikr includes verbal remembrance (saying SubhanAllah, etc.), remembrance in the heart, and remembrance through actions.

grammar.reason: The direct object of 'udhkurū' - WHO should be remembered. Accusative case as the object of the verb.
grammar.practical: Allah - in accusative case (fatha 'a' ending) because He is the object being remembered. 'Remember ALLAH!' The 'a' ending signals this is WHOM they should remember.
Preposition 'in' or 'during' - specifies WHEN to remember Allah.

grammar.case: Genitive (majrūr) - ends in kasrah with tanwīn (in)
grammar.reason: Refers to specific days during Hajj (days of Tashrīq). Genitive case due to preposition 'fī'. Indefinite but specified by the following adjective.
grammar.practical: Plural of 'yawm' (day) = 'ayyām' (days). The '-in' ending shows: 1) it's plural, 2) genitive case (after preposition 'fī'), and 3) has tanwīn (indefinite). These are 'days' - which days will be specified next.

grammar.reason: Describes the days as 'numbered/counted' - specifically the days of Tashrīq (11th, 12th, 13th of Dhul-Ḥijjah). Feminine plural agrees with 'ayyām'. Genitive to match the noun it describes.
grammar.practical: Means 'numbered' or 'counted' or 'appointed'. From root 'ʿadada' (to count). The pattern 'mafʿūl' indicates something that is counted/numbered. The feminine plural ending '-ātin' (with tanwīn kasrah 'in') matches 'ayyām'. 'Maʿdūdāt' means these are SPECIFIC, LIMITED days - not infinite. This refers to the days of Tashrīq during Hajj (the 11th, 12th, and 13th of Dhul-Ḥijjah) when pilgrims remember Allah and complete their Hajj rites.

grammar.reason: 'Fa' introduces the consequence/ruling, 'man' is the conditional pronoun meaning 'whoever'.
grammar.practical: Combination of 'fa' (so/then) + 'man' (whoever) = 'so whoever'. This introduces a conditional statement: 'whoever does X, then Y happens'. The 'fa' shows this is the ruling/consequence being explained.

grammar.tense: Past (but in conditional context means 'whoever hastens')
grammar.reason: Describes hastening or leaving early. Form V adds reflexive meaning - hastening oneself. In conditional sentences with 'man', past tense has present/future meaning.
grammar.practical: Means 'he hastens' or 'he hurries'. From root 'ʿajala' (to hasten). Form V (ta-X-X-ala pattern) adds reflexive meaning: 'he hastens himself' or 'he chooses to hasten'. Though grammatically past tense, with 'man' (whoever) it means 'whoever hastens' (present/future). This refers to pilgrims who choose to leave Mina early (after 2 days) instead of staying the full 3 days.
Indicates the time period - 'within' or 'in' how many days.

grammar.case: Genitive (majrūr) - dual ending in genitive is '-ayni'
grammar.reason: Dual form of 'yawm' (day). Genitive case due to preposition 'fī'. The '-ayni' ending is the signature of dual genitive/accusative.
grammar.practical: Means 'two days'. Arabic has special dual forms! 'Yawm' (day) → 'yawmān' (two days - nominative) or 'yawmayni' (two days - genitive/accusative). Here it's 'yawmayni' with the '-ayni' ending because it comes after preposition 'fī' (genitive case). This refers to leaving on the 12th day (after spending the 11th and 12th in Mina during Hajj).
'Fa' (so/then) + 'lā' (no) = 'then no' or 'so there is no'. This introduces the ruling: the RESULT is that there is NO (sin).

grammar.root: أ-ث-م (a-th-m) - to sin, to commit wrong
grammar.case: Accusative (manṣūb) - ends in fatha (a) due to 'lā'
grammar.reason: This is what's being negated - there is NO sin. Accusative case because of the negation particle 'lā'.
grammar.practical: Means 'sin' or 'wrongdoing'. From root 'athima' (to sin). The 'a' ending (fatha) is because of 'lā' - when 'lā' negates a noun, that noun takes fatha. 'Lā ithma' = 'no sin'. Beautiful ruling: if you leave early (after 2 days), there's NO SIN on you!

grammar.function: Shows who is free from sin
grammar.practical: 'ʿAlā' (upon/on) + 'hi' (him) = 'ʿalayhi' (upon him). Complete phrase: 'falā ithma ʿalayhi' = 'there is no sin upon him'. This shows the person who hastens has NO burden of sin for leaving early.
'Wa' (and) + 'man' (whoever) = 'and whoever'. Introduces the second case - those who stay longer.

grammar.root: أ-خ-ر (a-kh-r) - to delay, to put back, to come later
grammar.reason: Describes delaying or staying longer. Form V makes it reflexive - delaying oneself. With 'man', means 'whoever delays'.
grammar.practical: Means 'he delays' or 'he stays behind'. From root 'akhkhara' (to delay/postpone). Form V (ta-X-X-ara pattern) adds reflexive: 'he delays himself' or 'chooses to stay longer'. With 'man' (whoever), means 'whoever delays' or 'whoever stays' - referring to pilgrims who stay all 3 days in Mina (until the 13th).
Same as before: 'so there is no'.
Same word: 'sin'. 'No sin' for those who stay longer either!
Same phrase: 'upon him'. Complete: 'no sin upon him'. Beautiful balance: whether you leave early or stay longer, NO sin - both are permissible!

grammar.reason: Introduces a condition for this ruling. The genitive case affects 'man'.
grammar.practical: 'Li' (for) + 'mani' (whoever - in genitive) = 'limani' (for whoever). This adds an important condition: this ruling (no sin for leaving early or late) is FOR WHOEVER meets the following condition...

words.translation: has taqwa / is conscious of Allah / fears Allah

grammar.root: و-ق-ي (w-q-y) - to protect, to guard, to fear
grammar.reason: Describes the condition - having taqwā (God-consciousness). Form VIII adds reflexive meaning - protecting oneself (from Allah's displeasure).
grammar.practical: Means 'he had taqwā' or 'he was God-conscious'. From root 'waqā' (to protect). Form VIII (itta-X-ā pattern) creates 'ittaqā' meaning 'he protected himself' from Allah's displeasure = had taqwā. This is the CONDITION: this flexibility (leave early or stay) is for WHOEVER has taqwā - meaning they did all their rituals properly, avoided sins during Hajj, and have God-consciousness. Beautiful: Allah gives flexibility, but with the condition of maintaining piety!
Transitions to additional command.

words.translation: fear / be conscious of / have taqwa

grammar.reason: Direct command to have taqwā of Allah. Plural addresses the entire community.
grammar.practical: Command form: 'Have taqwā!' or 'Be conscious of Allah!' Same root as 'ittaqā'. The '-ū' ending makes it plural: 'You all have taqwā!' This is one of the most repeated commands in the Quran - constantly reminding believers to maintain God-consciousness in all affairs.
Allah in accusative case - the object of taqwā. 'Have taqwā of ALLAH!' The 'a' ending shows it's the object.
Adds another command.

grammar.root: ع-ل-م (ʿ-l-m) - to know, to have knowledge
grammar.reason: Command to know with certainty. The '-ū' makes it plural: addressing everyone.
grammar.practical: Command: 'Know!' From root 'ʿalima' (to know). The '-ū' ending: 'You all know!' This isn't just intellectual knowledge - it's a command to know with certainty and act upon what you know. What should we know? That's explained next...

grammar.reason: 'Anna' is an emphasizing particle that means 'that/indeed' and affects the following noun/pronoun to be in accusative. 'Kum' is the plural 'you'.
grammar.practical: 'Anna' (indeed/that) + 'kum' (you plural) = 'annakum' (indeed you/that you). This introduces what we must know with certainty. 'Anna' adds emphasis and certainty to the statement.
'Ilā' (to/toward) + 'hi' (Him) = 'ilayhi' (to Him). Shows the DESTINATION - to Allah you will return.

grammar.type: Fiʿl - Present/Future Passive Verb (Fiʿl Muḍāriʿ Majhūl)
grammar.reason: Passive voice shows they will BE gathered (by Allah). The 'tu-...-ūn' pattern indicates second person plural passive present/future.
grammar.practical: Means 'you will be gathered'. From root 'ḥashara' (to gather/assemble). The passive form (tuḥsharūna) means 'you WILL BE gathered' - Allah will gather you. The pattern 'tu-X-X-ūn' shows: 1) passive voice (you're being acted upon), 2) plural 'you', 3) present/future tense. Complete meaning: 'Know with certainty that you all will be gathered TO HIM (Allah)' - referring to the Day of Judgment. Powerful ending: after Hajj, after all your worship, remember you'll return to Allah for final accountability!

verses.arabic: وَمِنَ ٱلنَّاسِ مَن يُعْجِبُكَ قَوْلُهُۥ فِى ٱلْحَيَوٰةِ ٱلدُّنْيَا وَيُشْهِدُ ٱللَّهَ عَلَىٰ مَا فِى قَلْبِهِۦ وَهُوَ أَلَدُّ ٱلْخِصَامِ
verses.transliteration: Wamina n-nāsi man yuʿjibuka qawluhu fī l-ḥayāti d-dunyā wayush-hidu llāha ʿalā mā fī qalbihi wahuwa aladdu l-khiṣāmi
verses.translation: There are some hypocrites who impress you with their views regarding worldly affairs and openly call upon Allah to witness what is in their hearts, yet they are your worst adversaries.

grammar.practical: Connects to previous discussion, transitioning to describe a different type of person.
Preposition meaning 'from' or 'among'. Introduces a subset of people.

grammar.case: Genitive (majrūr) - ends in kasrah (i) due to 'min'
grammar.reason: Refers to people in general. Genitive case because it follows the preposition 'min'.
grammar.practical: Means 'the people' or 'mankind'. The 'i' ending shows genitive case after the preposition 'min'. Together: 'among the people' or 'from among mankind'.
Means 'who' or 'those who'. 'Among the people are those who...' - introducing a description of a specific type of person.

words.translation: impresses you / pleases you / amazes you

grammar.root: ع-ج-ب (ʿ-j-b) - to amaze, to please, to impress
grammar.person: Third person masculine singular with attached pronoun
grammar.reason: Describes the effect this person's speech has. Form IV makes it causative - 'causes you to be impressed'. The 'ka' pronoun specifies who is impressed.
grammar.practical: Means 'it impresses you' or 'it amazes you'. From root 'ʿajiba' (to be amazed). Form IV 'aʿjaba' means 'to cause amazement' or 'to impress'. 'Yuʿjibu' = 'it impresses', and 'ka' = 'you', so 'yuʿjibuka' = 'it impresses YOU'. This describes someone whose speech is so eloquent and seemingly sincere that it impresses you - but as we'll see, it's deceptive!

grammar.reason: This is the subject - WHAT impresses you. His speech is what causes the impression. Nominative as the subject of the verb.
grammar.practical: Means 'his speech' or 'his words'. From root 'qāla' (to say). 'Qawl' is the verbal noun meaning 'speech/saying', and 'hu' means 'his'. So 'qawluhu' = 'his speech'. This is the subject: HIS SPEECH is what impresses you. The 'u' ending shows nominative case - it's the doer of the impressing.
Preposition 'in' or 'concerning' - shows what topic his speech is about.

grammar.root: ح-ي-ي (ḥ-y-y) - to live, to be alive
grammar.case: Genitive (majrūr) - ends in kasrah (i) due to 'fī'
grammar.reason: Refers to life, specifically worldly life (as specified by next word). Genitive due to preposition.
grammar.practical: Means 'the life'. From root 'ḥayiya' (to live). The 'i' ending shows genitive case after 'fī'. This will be further specified by the next word as 'the worldly life'.

grammar.case: Genitive (majrūr) - matches the noun it describes
grammar.reason: Describes which life - the worldly/lower life. Agrees in case, gender, and definiteness with 'ḥayāh'.
grammar.practical: Means 'the worldly' or 'the lower'. Describes 'ḥayāh' (life). Together: 'al-ḥayāt ad-dunyā' = 'the worldly life'. His impressive speech is about WORLDLY MATTERS - business, politics, social issues. He sounds knowledgeable and sincere about this-worldly affairs, but as the verse reveals, it's just show!
Adds another quality of this hypocrite - he also swears by Allah.

words.translation: he calls to witness / he testifies

grammar.reason: Describes his habitual action of calling Allah as witness. Form IV means 'to make witness' or 'to call upon as witness'.
grammar.practical: Means 'he makes witness' or 'he calls upon to witness'. From root 'shahida' (to witness). Form IV 'ash-hada' means 'to call someone as witness' or 'to make someone testify'. The 'yu-' prefix shows present tense third person: 'he calls to witness'. This hypocrite constantly invokes Allah's name, swearing by Allah to prove his sincerity!

grammar.reason: The object of the verb - WHOM he calls as witness. Accusative as direct object.
grammar.practical: Allah - in accusative case (fatha 'a') as the object. He calls upon ALLAH as witness. This makes his deception even worse - he's using Allah's name falsely!

grammar.function: Indicates what Allah is called to witness about
grammar.practical: Preposition 'upon' or 'concerning' - introduces what he's asking Allah to witness.
Relative pronoun 'what' or 'that which'. Introduces what Allah is called to witness about.
Preposition 'in' - shows WHERE: in his heart.

grammar.case: Genitive (majrūr) - ends in kasrah (i) due to 'fī'
grammar.reason: Refers to his inner self/heart. Genitive due to preposition 'fī'. The possessive pronoun 'hi' refers back to the hypocrite.
grammar.practical: Means 'his heart'. From root 'qalaba' (to turn/flip) - the heart is called 'qalb' because it constantly turns/changes. 'Qalb' = heart, 'hi' = his. The 'i' ending shows genitive (after 'fī'). He calls Allah to witness WHAT IS IN HIS HEART - claiming his intentions are pure. But it's all lies! Beautiful irony: he swears by Allah while his heart is full of hypocrisy.
Conjunction introducing contrast: 'while' or 'yet'. Shows the shocking reality that contrasts with his outward appearance.

grammar.reason: Subject of the nominal sentence - emphasizing the reality of who he is.
grammar.practical: Personal pronoun 'he'. Acts as the subject, emphasizing: THIS PERSON, despite his impressive speech, HE IS actually...

words.translation: the fiercest / the most quarrelsome / the worst

grammar.root: ل-د-د (l-d-d) - to be fierce in dispute, to quarrel intensely
grammar.reason: Superlative form describing him as THE MOST fierce in quarreling. Nominative as predicate of nominal sentence.
grammar.practical: Means 'the most fierce' or 'the worst' in argumentation. From root 'ladda' (to be fierce in dispute/obstinate). The pattern 'afʿal' (like 'aladdu') creates the superlative: THE MOST fierce, THE WORST. This describes someone who argues fiercely with falsehood, twisting words, never admitting truth. Despite his eloquent speech, he's actually THE WORST type of arguer!

grammar.root: خ-ص-م (kh-ṣ-m) - to quarrel, to dispute, to oppose
grammar.reason: Specifies the domain of his being the worst - in quarreling/opposition. Genitive after the superlative 'aladdu'.
grammar.practical: Means 'quarreling' or 'disputation' or 'opponents'. From root 'khaṣama' (to dispute/quarrel). The 'i' ending shows genitive case after the superlative. Together: 'aladdu l-khiṣām' = 'the fiercest of quarrelers' or 'the worst of opponents'. Complete picture: This person speaks beautifully about worldly matters, swears by Allah about his pure intentions, BUT in reality he is the WORST, most fierce opponent - a complete hypocrite! This verse warns us not to be deceived by eloquent speech and false oaths.

verses.arabic: وَإِذَا تَوَلَّىٰ سَعَىٰ فِى ٱلْأَرْضِ لِيُفْسِدَ فِيهَا وَيُهْلِكَ ٱلْحَرْثَ وَٱلنَّسْلَ ۗ وَٱللَّهُ لَا يُحِبُّ ٱلْفَسَادَ
verses.transliteration: Wa-idhā tawallā saʿā fī l-arḍi li-yufsida fīhā wa-yuhlika l-ḥartha wa-n-nasla wa-llāhu lā yuḥibbu l-fasāda
verses.translation: And when they leave, they strive throughout the land to spread corruption in it and destroy crops and cattle. Allah does not like corruption.

grammar.practical: Continues describing the hypocrite from the previous verse.

grammar.reason: Indicates when the following action happens - sets up temporal condition.
grammar.practical: Means 'when' or 'whenever'. Introduces a time-based condition: 'WHEN this happens...' This sets up the scenario - when the hypocrite described in verse 204 turns away...

grammar.root: و-ل-ي (w-l-y) - to turn, to manage, to be in charge
grammar.reason: Describes turning away or leaving. Form V adds reflexive meaning - turning oneself away.
grammar.practical: Means 'he turned away' or 'he left'. From root 'waliya' (to turn/be in charge). Form V 'tawallā' means 'he turned himself away' or 'he left'. With 'idhā', means 'when he turns away'. This refers to when the hypocrite leaves from the Prophet's gathering - he showed one face in front of the Prophet, but when he leaves...

words.translation: he strives / he works / he goes about

grammar.root: س-ع-ي (s-ʿ-y) - to strive, to work, to endeavor
grammar.reason: Describes his actions after leaving - what he strives to do.
grammar.practical: Means 'he strove' or 'he worked' or 'he went about'. From root 'saʿā' (to strive/endeavor). This describes his EFFORTS and ACTIONS. But unlike righteous striving, this is evil striving as we'll see!
Preposition 'in' or 'throughout' - shows WHERE he strives.

grammar.case: Genitive (majrūr) - ends in kasrah (i) due to 'fī'
grammar.reason: Refers to the earth/land - the sphere where he spreads corruption. Genitive after preposition.
grammar.practical: Means 'the earth' or 'the land'. From root 'arḍ' (earth/land). The 'i' ending shows genitive case after 'fī'. He strives THROUGHOUT THE LAND - his corruption is widespread, not limited to one place!

words.translation: to cause corruption / to spread corruption

grammar.type: Harf + Fiʿl - Preposition + Present Subjunctive Verb
grammar.root: ف-س-د (f-s-d) - to be corrupt, to spoil
grammar.form: Form IV (ifʿāl) - causative, in subjunctive mood
grammar.components: li (to/in order to) + yufsida (he causes corruption)
grammar.reason: 'Li' makes the verb subjunctive, indicating purpose - he strives IN ORDER TO corrupt. Form IV makes it causative - causing corruption.
grammar.practical: Means 'in order to cause corruption'. 'Li' = 'to/in order to' (shows purpose). 'Yufsida' from root 'fasada' (to be corrupt). Form IV 'afsada' means 'to CAUSE corruption' or 'to make corrupt'. The subjunctive mood (after 'li') shows PURPOSE: he strives FOR THE PURPOSE of spreading corruption! This reveals his TRUE intent after leaving the Prophet's presence.

grammar.components: fī (in) + hā (it, referring to the earth)
grammar.practical: 'Fī' (in) + 'hā' (it/her - feminine pronoun referring to earth) = 'in it'. He causes corruption IN THE EARTH mentioned before.
Adds another evil action - not just general corruption, but specifically...

grammar.type: Fiʿl - Present Subjunctive Verb (Fiʿl Muḍāriʿ Manṣūb)
grammar.reason: Form IV makes it causative - causing destruction. Subjunctive mood coordinated with previous verb.
grammar.practical: Means 'he destroys'. From root 'halaka' (to perish/die). Form IV 'ahlaka' means 'to CAUSE to perish' or 'to destroy'. The subjunctive mood (coordinated with 'yufsida') shows this is also part of his purpose. He destroys what? Explained next...

grammar.root: ح-ر-ث (ḥ-r-th) - to plow, to till, to cultivate
grammar.reason: The direct object of 'yuhlika' - WHAT he destroys. Accusative as object of the verb.
grammar.practical: Means 'the crops' or 'the cultivation' or 'the tillage'. From root 'ḥaratha' (to plow/cultivate). 'Ḥarth' refers to cultivated land, crops, agriculture. The 'a' ending shows it's the object - he destroys THE CROPS. This includes burning fields, destroying agriculture, causing famine - all forms of economic destruction.
Adds the second object of destruction.

words.translation: the offspring / the livestock / the progeny

grammar.root: ن-س-ل (n-s-l) - to reproduce, to breed, to beget offspring
grammar.reason: Second object of 'yuhlika' - another thing he destroys. Accusative as direct object.
grammar.practical: Means 'the offspring', 'the progeny', or 'the livestock'. From root 'nasala' (to reproduce/breed). 'Nasl' refers to offspring - both animal (livestock) and human progeny. The 'a' ending shows it's the object. He destroys livestock (cattle, animals) and potentially causes loss of human life. Complete picture: this hypocrite destroys both CROPS (harth) and LIVESTOCK (nasl) - the two foundations of life and economy! He creates chaos, famine, and death.
Transitions to Allah's statement about this corruption.

grammar.reason: The subject of this sentence - Allah is described by what follows.
grammar.practical: Allah - in nominative case as the subject. The 'u' ending shows it's the subject. What does Allah say about this corruption?
Negation particle 'not'. Negates what follows: Allah does NOT...

grammar.reason: Describes Allah's attribute - He does not love corruption. Present tense indicates eternal, unchanging truth.
grammar.practical: Means 'He loves' or 'He likes'. From root 'ḥabba' (to love). The 'yu-' prefix shows present tense third person (He). With 'lā' before it: 'lā yuḥibbu' = 'He does NOT love'. This expresses Allah's eternal attribute - He never loves or approves of corruption.

grammar.root: ف-س-د (f-s-d) - to be corrupt, to spoil
grammar.reason: The object of 'yuḥibbu' - WHAT Allah does not love. Accusative as direct object.
grammar.practical: Means 'the corruption'. From root 'fasada' (to be corrupt/spoiled). 'Fasād' is the noun meaning corruption, mischief, decay, destruction. The 'a' ending shows it's the object. Complete statement: 'Allah does NOT love corruption.' This is both a statement of Allah's attribute AND a warning to the hypocrite - your corruption is HATED by Allah! Beautiful verse showing the contrast: the hypocrite speaks beautifully but acts corruptly, while Allah sees through the facade and declares His hatred for such corruption.

verses.arabic: وَإِذَا قِيلَ لَهُ ٱتَّقِ ٱللَّهَ أَخَذَتْهُ ٱلْعِزَّةُ بِٱلْإِثْمِ ۚ فَحَسْبُهُۥ جَهَنَّمُ ۚ وَلَبِئْسَ ٱلْمِهَادُ
verses.transliteration: Wa-idhā qīla lahu ittaqi l-laha akhadhathu l-ʿizatu bil-ithmi faḥasbuhu jahannamu walabi'sa l-mihādu
verses.translation: When it is said to them, 'Fear Allah,' pride carries them off to sin. Hell will be their proper place. What an evil place to rest!

grammar.practical: Continues the description of the hypocrite from verses 204-205.
Temporal particle 'when' - sets up another scenario about this hypocrite.

words.translation: it is said / it was said

grammar.type: Fiʿl - Past Passive Verb (Fiʿl Māḍī Majhūl)
grammar.reason: Passive voice - 'it is said' (by someone unspecified). Describes when advice is given to him.
grammar.practical: Passive form meaning 'it was said' or 'it is said'. From root 'qāla' (to say). Passive pattern makes the sayer unspecified - the focus is on what is SAID to him, not who says it. When advice is given to this hypocrite...
'La' (to) + 'hu' (him) = 'to him'. Shows WHO the advice is directed to - to this hypocrite.

words.translation: fear / be conscious of / have taqwa

grammar.root: و-ق-ي (w-q-y) - to protect, to fear, to be conscious
grammar.reason: Direct command to have taqwā - the actual words spoken to him. Imperative form shows it's advice/command.
grammar.practical: Command form: 'Fear!' or 'Have taqwā!' From root 'waqā'. Form VIII 'ittaqā' means 'to have taqwā/God-consciousness'. This is the sincere advice given to him: 'Fear Allah!' But watch his reaction...
Allah in accusative case - the object of taqwā. 'Fear ALLAH!' Complete advice: when someone tells him 'Fear Allah!'...

words.translation: it seizes him / it takes him

grammar.type: Fiʿl - Past Tense Verb with Pronoun
grammar.person: Third person feminine singular with object pronoun
grammar.reason: Describes what happens to him when advised. The feminine 't' refers to 'izzah (pride) which comes next. The 'hu' is the object - pride takes HIM.
grammar.practical: Means 'it seized him' or 'it took him'. From 'akhadha' (to take/seize). 'Akhadhat' = 'she/it took' (feminine), 'hu' = 'him'. Together: 'it seized him'. What seizes him? Explained next...

grammar.root: ع-ز-ز (ʿ-z-z) - to be mighty, to be proud
grammar.reason: The subject - PRIDE is what seizes him. Normally 'ʿizzah' means honor/might, but here with sin it means false pride/arrogance. Nominative as the doer.
grammar.practical: Means 'the pride' or 'the arrogance'. From root 'ʿazza' (to be mighty/proud). 'ʿIzzah' normally means honor or might, but here it's FALSE pride - arrogance. When told to fear Allah, instead of accepting the advice humbly, PRIDE seizes him! The 'u' ending shows it's the subject - pride is the doer.

grammar.reason: 'Bi' here means 'with' or 'leading to'. His pride leads him WITH/TO sin. Describes the consequence of his arrogance.
grammar.practical: 'Bi' (with/by/to) + 'al-ithm' (the sin). 'Ithm' means sin or wrongdoing. The 'i' ending shows genitive (after 'bi'). This phrase shows the RESULT: pride takes him WITH SIN or LEADS him TO sin. Instead of fearing Allah when advised, his arrogance drives him deeper into sin! 'Bi' here indicates accompaniment or result.

words.translation: then sufficient for him / so enough for him

grammar.type: Harf + Ism - Particle + Noun with Pronoun
grammar.root: ح-س-ب (ḥ-s-b) - to suffice, to be enough
grammar.reason: 'Fa' introduces consequence. 'Ḥasb' means sufficiency/enough. With pronoun: 'sufficient for him'. This introduces his punishment.
grammar.practical: 'Fa' (so/then) + 'ḥasb' (sufficiency/enough) + 'hu' (his/for him) = 'so sufficient for him' or 'then enough for him'. 'Ḥasb' comes from the root meaning 'to suffice'. This phrase introduces the consequence: 'So SUFFICIENT for him is...' What? The punishment mentioned next!

grammar.reason: The predicate - WHAT is sufficient for him. Jahannam (Hell) is enough as his punishment. Nominative as the khabar.
grammar.practical: Jahannam - the name of Hell in Arabic. The 'u' ending shows nominative case as the predicate. Complete meaning: 'So sufficient for him is HELL' or 'Hell is enough for him'. Powerful statement: his arrogance when advised to fear Allah earns him Hell!
Adds further emphasis about Hell.

words.translation: indeed how evil / what a terrible

grammar.type: Harf + Fiʿl - Particle + Verb of Blame (Fiʿl Dhamm)
grammar.root: ب-ء-س (b-'-s) - to be evil, to be bad
grammar.reason: 'La' adds emphasis. 'Bi'sa' is a special verb used only for expressing blame/condemnation. Means 'how evil' or 'what a terrible'.
grammar.practical: 'La' (indeed/verily) + 'bi'sa' (how evil/how terrible). 'Bi'sa' is a unique Arabic verb used ONLY to express condemnation - it's never used in any other context! It means 'How EVIL!' or 'What a TERRIBLE!' The 'la' at the beginning adds extra emphasis. Together: 'INDEED how evil!' or 'What a TERRIBLE!'. What is terrible? Explained next...

words.translation: the resting place / the bed / the abode

grammar.root: م-هـ-د (m-h-d) - to prepare, to make smooth, to cradle
grammar.reason: Specifies WHAT is evil - the resting place (i.e., Hell). 'Mihād' literally means a prepared bed/resting place, ironically used for Hell.
grammar.practical: Means 'the resting place' or 'the bed' or 'the abode'. From root 'mahada' (to prepare/smooth out). 'Mihād' is a prepared, smooth bed - a place of rest. But here it's used IRONICALLY for Hell! Complete statement: 'What an EVIL resting place!' or 'How TERRIBLE a bed (Hell is)!' The irony is powerful: instead of a comfortable bed, his 'resting place' is the torment of Hell! This verse paints a complete picture: arrogant when advised, Hell as his reward, and what a terrible 'bed' he'll rest in!

verses.arabic: وَمِنَ ٱلنَّاسِ مَن يَشْرِى نَفْسَهُ ٱبْتِغَآءَ مَرْضَاتِ ٱللَّهِ ۗ وَٱللَّهُ رَءُوفٌۢ بِٱلْعِبَادِ
verses.transliteration: Wamina n-nāsi man yashrī nafsahu ibtigħāa marḍāti llāhi wa-llāhu raūfun bil-ʿibādi
verses.translation: There are those among people who dedicate their lives seeking Allah's pleasure. Allah shows compassion to His servants.

grammar.practical: Transitions to describe the opposite type of person - contrasting with the hypocrite in verses 204-206.
Preposition 'from' or 'among' - introduces another subset of people.
'The people' in genitive case after 'min'. Same construction as verse 204, but NOW describing the OPPOSITE type.
'Who' or 'those who' - introduces the characteristics of these righteous people.

words.translation: he sells / he trades / he sacrifices

grammar.root: ش-ر-ي (sh-r-y) - to buy, to sell, to trade
grammar.reason: Describes the action of selling/trading. Here it means sacrificing or dedicating.
grammar.practical: Means 'he sells' or 'he trades'. From root 'sharā' (to buy/sell). In this context, 'yashrī nafsahu' means 'he sells/sacrifices his self' - dedicating his entire life. Present tense shows it's their constant state. What does he sacrifice? His very SELF (life)...

words.translation: his self / his soul / his life

grammar.reason: The object of 'yashrī' - what he sells/sacrifices. His entire self/life.
grammar.practical: Means 'his self' or 'his soul/life'. 'Nafs' = self/soul, 'hu' = his. Accusative case (object). He sells/sacrifices HIS VERY SELF - meaning he dedicates his entire life, puts everything on the line. Beautiful contrast with the hypocrite who destroyed crops - this believer destroys his own comfort for Allah's sake!

grammar.reason: Shows the PURPOSE or REASON for selling himself - he does it FOR THE PURPOSE of seeking...
grammar.practical: Verbal noun meaning 'seeking' or 'desiring'. From root 'bagh ā' (to seek). Form VIII 'ibtaghā' intensifies: seeking earnestly. Accusative case shows REASON/PURPOSE: he sacrifices himself FOR THE SEEKING of... what? Allah's pleasure!

grammar.root: ر-ض-ي (r-ḍ-y) - to be pleased, to be satisfied
grammar.reason: First part of construct - seeking THE PLEASURE. Will be specified whose pleasure in next word.
grammar.practical: Means 'pleasure' or 'satisfaction'. From root 'raḍiya' (to be pleased). 'Marḍāh' is the noun form. In construct form (will connect to next word): seeking THE PLEASURE of...

grammar.reason: Completes the construct - whose pleasure is sought. ALLAH's pleasure!
grammar.practical: Allah in genitive case (ends in 'i'). Completes the phrase: 'marḍāt Allāh' = 'Allah's pleasure'. Beautiful complete meaning: among people are those who SACRIFICE THEIR ENTIRE LIVES seeking ALLAH'S PLEASURE! This is the highest goal - not seeking worldly gain, but only Allah's satisfaction!
Transitions to Allah's response to such dedication.
Allah as the subject - now Allah's attribute is mentioned.

grammar.root: ر-ء-ف / ر-أ-ف (r-'-f) - to be compassionate, to be kind
grammar.reason: Describes Allah's permanent, intense quality of compassion. The 'faʿūl' pattern emphasizes the intensity.
grammar.practical: Means 'Most Compassionate' or 'Extremely Kind'. From root 'ra'afa' (to be compassionate). The pattern 'faʿūl' (like ra'ūf) shows INTENSE, PERMANENT quality - Allah is EXTREMELY compassionate! The 'un' tanwīn adds indefiniteness and magnificence. Beautiful promise: those who sacrifice for Allah will find Him MOST COMPASSIONATE!

words.translation: to the servants / with the servants

grammar.reason: 'ʿIbād' is plural of 'ʿabd' (servant/worshipper). Shows WHO receives Allah's compassion - His servants.
grammar.practical: 'Bi' (to/with) + 'al-ʿibād' (the servants). 'ʿIbād' is the plural of 'ʿabd' meaning 'servants' or 'worshippers'. Complete: 'Allah is Most Compassionate TO His servants'. Beautiful ending: those who serve Allah faithfully will find Him full of compassion toward them. Perfect contrast to verse 204-206: the arrogant hypocrite earns Hell, while the humble servant finds Allah's compassion!

verses.arabic: يَـٰٓأَيُّهَا ٱلَّذِينَ ءَامَنُوا۟ ٱدْخُلُوا۟ فِى ٱلسِّلْمِ كَآفَّةًۭ وَلَا تَتَّبِعُوا۟ خُطُوَٰتِ ٱلشَّيْطَـٰنِ ۚ إِنَّهُۥ لَكُمْ عَدُوٌّۭ مُّبِينٌۭ
verses.transliteration: Yā ayyuhā alladhīna āmanū udkhulū fī s-silmi kāffatan walā tattabiʿū khuṭuwāti sh-shayṭāni innahu lakum ʿaduwwun mubīn
verses.translation: O believers! Enter into Islam wholeheartedly and do not follow Satan's footsteps. Surely he is your sworn enemy.

grammar.practical: 'Yā' is the vocative particle (like saying 'O!'), and 'ayyuhā' means 'you who' or 'those who'. Together: 'O you who...!' This is how the Quran addresses believers directly - calling their attention for something important!
Plural relative pronoun 'those who' - specifies WHO is being addressed.

grammar.root: أ-م-ن (a-m-n) - to believe, to have faith
grammar.practical: Past tense verb 'they believed'. The '-ū' ending shows plural. Complete address: 'O you who have believed!' This is a direct call to all Muslims.

grammar.reason: Direct command to the believers. Plural 'ū' addresses everyone.
grammar.practical: Command form: 'Enter!' From root 'dakhala' (to enter). The '-ū' makes it plural: 'You all enter!' This is a command to believers: ENTER! But enter into what?...
Preposition 'in' or 'into' - shows WHERE/WHAT to enter.

grammar.root: س-ل-م (s-l-m) - to be safe, to submit, to have peace
grammar.reason: 'Silm' means Islam/peace/submission - all from same root. Here it means complete Islam.
grammar.practical: Means 'Islam' or 'peace' or 'submission'. From root 'salima' (to be safe/peaceful). 'Silm' and 'Islām' share the same root - both mean submission to Allah and the peace that comes from it. The 'i' ending shows genitive case. Command: 'Enter INTO ISLAM' - meaning practice Islam COMPLETELY, not partially!

grammar.root: ك-ف-ف (k-f-f) - to restrain, to hold back, to encompass
grammar.reason: Describes HOW to enter - completely, entirely, all aspects. The tanwīn 'an' shows it's a ḥāl (state/manner).
grammar.practical: Means 'all together' or 'completely' or 'wholeheartedly'. From root 'kaffa' (to encompass/restrain). 'Kāffah' means 'all of it' or 'entirely'. The '-an' tanwīn shows it's an adverb describing the MANNER: enter Islam COMPLETELY, WHOLEHEARTEDLY! Don't pick and choose - embrace ALL of Islam! This is crucial: you can't say 'I like prayer but not fasting' - enter Islam ENTIRELY!
Adds a prohibition after the command.
Prohibition particle 'do not' - with present tense verb creates prohibition.

grammar.reason: Form VIII adds intensity - to follow closely/persistently. Jussive mood with 'lā' creates prohibition.
grammar.practical: Means 'follow' or 'pursue'. From root 'tabiʿa' (to follow). Form VIII 'ittabaʿa' means to follow closely/persistently. With 'lā' before it: 'lā tattabiʿū' = 'do NOT follow'. The '-ū' is plural. Don't follow what?...

grammar.reason: The object of 'tattabiʿū' - WHAT not to follow. 'Khuṭuwāt' is plural of 'khuṭwah' (step). In construct with next word.
grammar.practical: Means 'footsteps' or 'steps'. Plural of 'khuṭwah' (a step). Accusative case (object of the verb). In construct form: 'footsteps OF...' whose footsteps? The next word reveals...

grammar.root: ش-ط-ن (sh-ṭ-n) - to be distant, to rebel
grammar.reason: Completes the construct - the footsteps OF SATAN. Genitive in possessive construction.
grammar.practical: Shaytān (Satan/Devil) in genitive case. From root meaning 'to be distant' (from Allah's mercy) or 'to rebel'. Complete phrase: 'footsteps of Satan' - meaning Satan's path, his methods, his ways. 'Don't follow Satan's footsteps' means don't even take small steps toward evil - each sin is a 'step' in Satan's path!

grammar.reason: 'Inna' adds emphasis. With pronoun 'hu' refers to Satan. Introduces strong statement.
grammar.practical: 'Inna' (indeed/verily) + 'hu' (he) = 'indeed he' or 'verily he'. 'Inna' is an emphatic particle that adds certainty and emphasis. Referring to Satan: 'Indeed HE (Satan)...' - strong statement about Satan's nature coming...
'La' (for/to) + 'kum' (you all) = 'for you' or 'to you'. He is FOR YOU - meaning in relation to you...

grammar.root: ع-د-و (ʿ-d-w) - to be hostile, to transgress
grammar.reason: The predicate - WHAT Satan is. The 'faʿūl' pattern shows intensity - a STRONG enemy.
grammar.practical: Means 'enemy'. From root 'ʿadā' (to be hostile). The pattern 'faʿūl' (like 'ʿaduww') shows an intense, persistent quality - not just any enemy, but a FIERCE, RELENTLESS enemy! The 'un' tanwīn adds indefiniteness and emphasis. Satan is AN ENEMY - a terrible one!

grammar.root: ب-ي-ن (b-y-n) - to be clear, to clarify
grammar.reason: Describes the type of enemy - a CLEAR, MANIFEST enemy. Everyone should recognize his enmity.
grammar.practical: Means 'clear' or 'manifest' or 'evident'. From root 'bayyana' (to clarify). Form IV active participle 'mubīn' means 'making clear' or 'being obvious'. Complete description: 'an enemy, CLEAR/MANIFEST'. Meaning Satan's enmity is OBVIOUS - no doubt about it! He's not a hidden enemy - his hatred for humans is CLEAR and EVIDENT! Complete verse: Enter Islam completely, don't follow Satan's path, because he is your CLEAR, MANIFEST enemy!

verses.arabic: فَإِن زَلَلْتُم مِّنۢ بَعْدِ مَا جَآءَتْكُمُ ٱلْبَيِّنَـٰتُ فَٱعْلَمُوٓا۟ أَنَّ ٱللَّهَ عَزِيزٌ حَكِيمٌ
verses.transliteration: Fa-in zalaltum min baʿdi mā jāatkumu l-bayinātu fa-iʿlamū anna llāha ʿazīzun ḥakīmun
verses.translation: If you falter after receiving the clear proofs, then know that Allah is indeed Almighty, All-Wise.

grammar.practical: 'Fa' (so/then) + 'in' (if) = conditional: 'so if'. Introduces a warning condition.

words.translation: you slip / you falter / you deviate

grammar.practical: 'You all slipped/faltered'. From root 'zalla' (to slip/err). The '-tum' ending = 'you plural'. Warning: IF you slip from the straight path...
'Min baʿd' = 'after'. Specifies WHEN - after what?
'What' - introduces what came to you.
'It came to you'. What came? The clear proofs (feminine noun bayināt)...
'The clear proofs' - evidences of truth (Quran, miracles, guidance). Plural of 'bayyinah'. After these clear proofs reach you, IF you still falter...
'Fa' (then/so) + command 'iʿlamū' (know!). Then KNOW with certainty...
'That' or 'indeed' - introduces what they must know with emphasis.
Allah in accusative case after 'anna'. Know that ALLAH...
Means 'Almighty' or 'All-Powerful'. Allah can punish those who deviate - He is not weak!
'All-Wise' - His punishment is just and wise, not arbitrary. Together: Know that Allah is Almighty (can punish) and All-Wise (punishes with perfect justice).

verses.arabic: هَلْ يَنظُرُونَ إِلَّآ أَن يَأْتِيَهُمُ ٱللَّهُ فِى ظُلَلٍ مِّنَ ٱلْغَمَامِ وَٱلْمَلَـٰٓئِكَةُ وَقُضِىَ ٱلْأَمْرُ ۚ وَإِلَى ٱللَّهِ تُرْجَعُ ٱلْأُمُورُ
verses.transliteration: Hal yanẓurūna illā an yatiyahumu llāhu fī ẓulalin mina l-ghamāmi wal-malāikatu wa-quḍiya l-amru wa-ilā llāhi turjaʿu l-umūru
verses.translation: Are they waiting for Allah to come to them in the shade of clouds, along with the angels? If He did, then the matter would be settled at once. And to Allah all matters will be returned for judgment.

grammar.practical: Question particle 'Do...?' or 'Are...?' - introduces rhetorical question.

words.translation: they wait / they look / they expect

grammar.practical: 'They wait' or 'they look for'. The '-ūna' ending = 'they'. Rhetorical question: Are they waiting for...?
'Except' or 'only' - limits what they're waiting for to ONE thing only.
'That' - introduces the verbal clause (what they wait for).
'He comes to them' or 'it comes to them'. Who comes?
Allah comes - referring to the Day of Judgment when Allah's command manifests.
Preposition 'in' - describes the circumstance.
'Shades' or 'canopies' (plural of 'ẓullah'). In shades of...
'From' or 'of' - specifies what kind of shades.
'The clouds'. Shades FROM clouds - meaning Allah's command comes with awesome signs (clouds, angels).
'And the angels' - angels also come. Complete picture: Are they waiting for the Day when Allah's judgment comes with clouds and angels?

words.translation: and it is decreed / it is settled

grammar.practical: 'And it was decreed' - passive voice. When that day comes, the matter will be SETTLED (too late for repentance).
'The matter' or 'the affair' - meaning judgment, decision. The matter will be SETTLED - finalized!
'And to' - shows destination of return.
Allah in genitive. TO Allah (all returns).
'Are returned' or 'will be returned' - passive voice. All matters WILL BE returned (to Allah for judgment).
'The matters' or 'the affairs' (plural of 'amr'). ALL matters return to Allah. Powerful ending: Don't wait for that Day - prepare NOW!

verses.arabic: سَلْ بَنِىٓ إِسْرَٰٓءِيلَ كَمْ ءَاتَيْنَـٰهُم مِّنْ ءَايَةٍۭ بَيِّنَةٍۢ ۗ وَمَن يُبَدِّلْ نِعْمَةَ ٱللَّهِ مِنۢ بَعْدِ مَا جَآءَتْهُ فَإِنَّ ٱللَّهَ شَدِيدُ ٱلْعِقَابِ
verses.transliteration: Sal banī isrāīla kam ātaynāhum min āyatin bayyinatin wa-man yubaddil niʿmata llāhi min baʿdi mā jāathu fa-inna llāha shadīdu l-ʿiqābi
verses.translation: Ask the Children of Israel how many clear signs We have given them. And whoever trades Allah's favour—after receiving it—for disbelief should know that Allah is indeed severe in punishment.

grammar.practical: 'Ask!' Command form from root 'sa'ala' (to ask/question). Singular imperative addressing the Prophet. This rhetorical question reminds of historical lessons.
grammar.reason: Direct command to the Prophet to ask a rhetorical question.

grammar.practical: 'Banī' = 'children of' or 'sons of' (construct form). Accusative as the object of 'ask'. Used with tribal/family names: 'Banī Israel' = 'Children of Israel'.
grammar.reason: First part of construct phrase.

grammar.practical: 'Israel' (Prophet Jacob's name, peace be upon him) in genitive case. Complete phrase: 'Banī Isrāīl' = 'Children of Israel' - the Israelites/Jews. They received many clear signs from Allah.
grammar.reason: Prophet Jacob's other name. His descendants = Children of Israel.

grammar.practical: 'How many' - interrogative asking about quantity. This introduces the rhetorical question: how many signs did We give them?
grammar.reason: Question word asking about quantity/number.

grammar.practical: 'We gave them'. From root 'atā' (to give). Form IV 'ātā' = 'to give/grant'. 'nā' = We (Allah), 'hum' = them. One word packs subject and object! Allah is asking: how many signs did WE GIVE THEM?
grammar.reason: Compound: ātay (He gave) + nā (We) + hum (them).

grammar.practical: Preposition 'from' or 'of' - here partitive, indicating the TYPE of what was given.
grammar.reason: Partitive 'of' - indicates type.

grammar.practical: 'Sign' or 'miracle'. From root meaning 'sign/proof'. Genitive case with tanwīn (-in). 'Āyah' can mean Quranic verse or miracle/sign. Here: miracles/signs given to Children of Israel.
grammar.reason: Signs/miracles given to them. Tanwīn shows indefinite magnificence.

grammar.practical: 'Clear' or 'evident'. Adjective describing 'āyah'. Genitive to match. Pattern shows intensity: VERY clear signs! How many CLEAR signs did Allah give them? Many! Yet they still disbelieved.
grammar.reason: Describes the signs as clear and evident.

grammar.practical: 'And whoever' - conditional statement. Transitions to a warning about those who reject Allah's favors.
grammar.reason: Introduces conditional warning.

grammar.practical: 'Changes' or 'replaces'. From root 'badala' (to change). Form II 'baddala' intensifies: to completely replace/change. Whoever CHANGES or TRADES (Allah's favor for disbelief)...
grammar.reason: Form II adds intensity - completely changing/replacing.

grammar.practical: 'Favor' or 'blessing'. From root 'naʿima' (to be blessed). In construct form: 'niʿmat' (favor OF...). Accusative as object - this is WHAT they're changing/trading.
grammar.reason: Object of the verb - what is being traded away.

grammar.practical: Allah in genitive. Complete: 'niʿmat Allāh' = 'Allah's favor/blessing'. Whoever trades ALLAH'S FAVOR (signs, guidance, truth) for disbelief...
grammar.reason: Completes phrase: Allah's favor.

grammar.practical: 'After' - prepositional phrase indicating time. After what?
grammar.reason: Temporal: after.

grammar.practical: 'What' - relative pronoun introducing what happened.
grammar.reason: Introduces relative clause.

grammar.practical: 'It came to him'. Feminine verb (niʿmah is feminine) + 'hu' (him). After the favor CAME TO HIM, if he then rejects it...
grammar.reason: Feminine verb (refers to niʿmah) + object pronoun.

grammar.practical: 'Then indeed' - 'fa' (then/so) + 'inna' (indeed/verily). Emphatic introduction to the consequence.
grammar.reason: Introduces emphatic consequence.

grammar.practical: Allah in accusative case after 'inna'. Indeed ALLAH...
grammar.reason: After 'inna', noun takes accusative.

grammar.practical: 'Severe' or 'intense'. Pattern 'faʿīl' shows intensity. In construct: 'shadīd' (severe IN...). Allah is SEVERE in...
grammar.reason: First part of construct describing Allah's attribute.

grammar.practical: 'The punishment'. From root 'ʿaqaba' (to punish). Genitive completing phrase: 'shadīd al-ʿiqāb' = 'severe IN punishment'. Warning: Allah is SEVERE in punishing those who reject His favors! Complete message: Look at Children of Israel - given so many clear signs, yet many rejected. Don't make the same mistake! Allah's punishment is severe.
grammar.reason: Completes phrase: severe in punishment.

verses.arabic: زُيِّنَ لِلَّذِينَ كَفَرُوا۟ ٱلْحَيَوٰةُ ٱلدُّنْيَا وَيَسْخَرُونَ مِنَ ٱلَّذِينَ ءَامَنُوا۟ ۘ وَٱلَّذِينَ ٱتَّقَوْا۟ فَوْقَهُمْ يَوْمَ ٱلْقِيَـٰمَةِ ۗ وَٱللَّهُ يَرْزُقُ مَن يَشَآءُ بِغَيْرِ حِسَابٍۢ
verses.transliteration: Zuyyina lilladhīna kafarū l-ḥayātu d-dunyā wa-yaskharūna mina lladhīna āmanū wa-lladhīna ttaqaw fawqahum yawma l-qiyāmati wa-llāhu yarzuqu man yashāu bi-ghayri ḥisābin
verses.translation: The life of this world has been beautified for those who disbelieve, and they ridicule the believers. Those mindful of Allah shall rank above them on Judgment Day. Allah provides for whom He wills without measure.

words.translation: it has been beautified / made attractive

grammar.practical: Passive form from root z-y-n (to beautify). 'It was made beautiful' - passive shows the worldly life appears attractive to disbelievers, though it's deceptive.
'Li' (for) + 'alladhīna' (those who). For WHOM was it beautified?
From k-f-r (to disbelieve/reject). Third plural past: 'they disbelieved'. For the disbelievers, worldly life seems beautiful.
Nominative subject. 'The life' - what was beautified.
Describes which life - the worldly, lower life. This worldly life appears beautiful to disbelievers.
From s-kh-r (to mock). Present tense third plural: 'they mock'. Not only do they love this world, they MOCK believers who prioritize the afterlife!
Preposition 'from' or 'at' - they mock AT...
Those who - introduces who they mock.
Form IV past: 'they believed'. They mock the BELIEVERS - those who value faith over materialism.

words.translation: and those who / but those who

grammar.practical: Contrastive: 'but those who' - introduces the believers' true status.
Form VIII past from w-q-y: 'they had taqwā'. Those who were conscious of Allah...
'Fawq' (above) + 'hum' (them). The believers will be ABOVE the disbelievers - higher rank!
Accusative adverb: 'on the Day'. WHEN will believers be above? On the Day of...
Genitive after time reference. Day of Qiyāmah (Resurrection/Judgment). Beautiful reversal: mockers think they're above believers now, but on Judgment Day, the believers will be FAR above them!
Allah as subject - introduces Allah's attribute.
From r-z-q (to provide). 'He provides' - Allah is the Provider.
'Whom' or 'whoever' - Allah provides to whomever...
From sh-y-' (to will). 'He wills' - Allah's will. He provides to whomever He wills, based on His wisdom.
'Bi' (with/by) + 'ghayr' (other than) = 'without'. Allah provides WITHOUT...
From ḥ-s-b (to calculate). 'Calculation' or 'measure'. Without ḥisāb = without LIMIT, endlessly! Allah's provision is LIMITLESS!

verses.arabic: كَانَ ٱلنَّاسُ أُمَّةً وَٰحِدَةً فَبَعَثَ ٱللَّهُ ٱلنَّبِيِّـۧنَ مُبَشِّرِينَ وَمُنذِرِينَ وَأَنزَلَ مَعَهُمُ ٱلْكِتَـٰبَ بِٱلْحَقِّ لِيَحْكُمَ بَيْنَ ٱلنَّاسِ فِيمَا ٱخْتَلَفُوا۟ فِيهِ ۚ وَمَا ٱخْتَلَفَ فِيهِ إِلَّا ٱلَّذِينَ أُوتُوهُ مِنۢ بَعْدِ مَا جَآءَتْهُمُ ٱلْبَيِّنَـٰتُ بَغْيًۢا بَيْنَهُمْ ۖ فَهَدَى ٱللَّهُ ٱلَّذِينَ ءَامَنُوا۟ لِمَا ٱخْتَلَفُوا۟ فِيهِ مِنَ ٱلْحَقِّ بِإِذْنِهِۦ ۗ وَٱللَّهُ يَهْدِى مَن يَشَآءُ إِلَىٰ صِرَٰطٍۢ مُّسْتَقِيمٍ
verses.transliteration: Kāna n-nāsu ummatan wāḥidatan fa-baʿatha llāhu n-nabiyyīna mubashshirīna wa-mundhirīna
verses.translation: Humanity was once one community. Then Allah raised prophets as deliverers of good news and warners, and revealed the Scripture with them to judge between people regarding their disputes.

grammar.practical: 'Was' or 'were' - from the special 'kāna' verbs that express past state of being. Introduces past condition: Humanity WAS...
'The people' or 'humanity' in nominative case. Subject of 'kāna'. ALL humanity at the beginning...
'One community' or 'one nation'. From root '-m-m (mother, nation). Accusative as predicate of 'kāna'. Originally, humanity was ONE community on truth.
'One' or 'single' - emphasizes unity. Feminine agreeing with 'ummah'. Accusative with tanwīn. ONE united community!
From b-ʿ-th (to send/raise). 'So He sent' - when people differed, Allah sent prophets. The 'fa' shows consequence.
Allah in nominative - the Subject who sent prophets.
'The prophets' in accusative (object of 'sent'). From n-b-' (to inform/prophesy). Allah sent THE PROPHETS to guide humanity back to truth!
Active participle from b-sh-r (good news). Form II intensive: those who bring MUCH good news! Accusative plural masculine. Prophets bring glad tidings of Paradise for believers.
Active participle from n-dh-r (to warn). Form IV: those who warn. Accusative plural. Prophets also warn of Hell for disbelievers. Complete picture: prophets bring BOTH good news AND warning!
Form IV from n-z-l (to descend). 'He sent down' or 'revealed'. Allah revealed scripture WITH the prophets.
'Maʿa' (with) + 'hum' (them). WITH the prophets - scriptures accompanied prophets for guidance.
'The Book' or 'Scripture' in accusative. From k-t-b (to write). Allah revealed scriptures to guide people.
'Bi' (with) + 'al-ḥaqq' (the truth). The scripture was revealed WITH TRUTH - containing only truth, no falsehood!
'Li' (to/in order to) + 'yaḥkuma' (he judges). Subjunctive mood showing PURPOSE: the scripture was revealed IN ORDER TO judge/decide between people's disputes.
'Between' - shows the scripture judges BETWEEN people in their disagreements.
'The people' in genitive (after 'bayna'). To judge BETWEEN the people.
'Fī' (in) + 'mā' (what) = 'in what' or 'regarding what'. Judges them regarding WHAT they differed in.
Form VIII from kh-l-f (to differ/disagree). Reflexive: 'they differed among themselves'. What did they differ about? Explained: religious matters, truth, etc.
'Fī' (in) + 'hi' (it). Differed IN IT - in matters of religion and truth.
'And not' - introduces what DIDN'T happen or who DIDN'T differ.
Same verb as before: 'differed'. Who differed? Explained next...
'In it' - same phrase, referring to the scripture/truth.
'Except' or 'only' - limits who differed. Only THESE people differed...
'Those who' - introduces who differed. Those who WHAT?

Form IV passive from '-t-y (to give). 'They were given it'. Passive: ūtū (they were given) + hu (it). Those who were GIVEN the scripture are the ones who differed! Ironic: they received guidance but still disagreed!
'After' - temporal phrase. After WHAT?
'What' - introduces what came after.
From j-y-' (to come). Feminine verb jāat (came) + hum (them). What came to them?
'The clear proofs' or 'clear evidences'. Plural of bayyinah. Even AFTER clear proofs came, they still differed! Why?
From b-gh-y (to transgress/envy). Accusative showing REASON: they differed due to ENVY and transgression among themselves - not because truth was unclear!
'Bayna' (between/among) + 'hum' (them). Envy AMONG themselves caused the differences.
From h-d-y (to guide). 'So He guided' - despite their differences, Allah guided those who believed.
Allah as subject - He guided.
'Those who' - WHO did Allah guide?
Form IV: 'they believed'. Allah guided THE BELIEVERS to the truth despite others' disagreements!
'Li' (to) + 'mā' (what). Guided them TO WHAT others differed about.
Same verb: 'differed'. Guided believers to the TRUTH that others differed about.
'About it' - regarding the truth.
'Of' or 'from' - specifies the TYPE.
'The truth' in genitive. Guided them to the TRUTH (not falsehood!) that others disputed.
'Bi' (by) + 'idhn' (permission) + 'hi' (His). From '-dh-n. By ALLAH'S PERMISSION - guidance comes only from Allah!
Allah as subject - general statement about Allah's guidance.
From h-d-y. 'He guides' - present tense shows continuing truth: Allah GUIDES...
'Whom' or 'whoever' - Allah guides whoever...
From sh-y-' (to will). 'He wills' - Allah guides whomever He wills (based on their sincerity and seeking).
'To' - shows destination of guidance.
'A path' or 'a way'. From root meaning 'path/road'. With tanwīn (indefinite) - but what kind of path?

From q-w-m (to be straight). Form X active participle: 'straight' or 'upright'. With tanwīn. A STRAIGHT path - not crooked! Complete: Allah guides whom He wills to a STRAIGHT PATH (Islam, truth, guidance)!

verses.arabic: أَمْ حَسِبْتُمْ أَن تَدْخُلُوا۟ ٱلْجَنَّةَ وَلَمَّا يَأْتِكُم مَّثَلُ ٱلَّذِينَ خَلَوْا۟ مِن قَبْلِكُم ۖ مَّسَّتْهُمُ ٱلْبَأْسَآءُ وَٱلضَّرَّآءُ وَزُلْزِلُوا۟ حَتَّىٰ يَقُولَ ٱلرَّسُولُ وَٱلَّذِينَ ءَامَنُوا۟ مَعَهُۥ مَتَىٰ نَصْرُ ٱللَّهِ ۗ أَلَآ إِنَّ نَصْرَ ٱللَّهِ قَرِيبٌۭ
verses.transliteration: Am ḥasibtum an tadkhulū l-jannata wa-lammā ya'tikum mathalu lladhīna khalaw min qablikum massathumu l-ba'sā'u wa-ḍḍarrā'u wa-zulzilū ḥattā yaqūla r-rasūlu wa-lladhīna āmanū maʿahu matā naṣru llāhi alā inna naṣra llāhi qarībun
verses.translation: Do you think you will enter Paradise without being tested like those before you? They were afflicted with hardship and adversity, and were so shaken that even the Messenger and believers with him cried out, 'When will Allah's help come?' Indeed, Allah's help is always near.

grammar.practical: Rhetorical question particle 'or' or 'do you think'. Challenges false assumptions.
From ḥ-s-b (to think/reckon). Second plural past: 'you all thought'. Do you THINK (mistakenly)?
'That' - introduces the thought clause.
From d-kh-l (to enter). Subjunctive after 'an'. Second plural: 'you enter'. Do you think you'll enter...?
'Paradise' or 'the Garden' in accusative. From j-n-n (to cover/hide). Called 'Jannah' because its trees cover/shade. Do you think you'll enter PARADISE...?
'Wa' (and) + 'lammā' (not yet). Emphasizes something hasn't happened YET. While you haven't yet...
From '-t-y (to come). Present ya'tī + kum (you plural). While it hasn't COME TO YOU yet...
'The like of' or 'the example of'. From m-th-l (to be like). In construct form. The like/example OF...
'Those who' - introduces who is being compared.
From kh-l-w (to pass away/precede). Third plural past: 'they passed'. Those who PASSED before (previous generations)...
'Min' (from) + 'qabl' (before) + 'kum' (you). From BEFORE you - previous believers. Complete thought: Do you think you'll enter Paradise without experiencing what previous believers experienced?
From m-s-s (to touch/afflict). Feminine past massat + hum (them). What touched them? Trials and hardships...
'Hardship' or 'distress'. From b-'-s (to be severe). Nominative subject. Physical/material hardship touched them!
'And adversity' or 'harm'. From ḍ-r-r (to harm). Coordinated subject. Mental/emotional suffering! They faced BOTH physical hardship AND emotional adversity!
From z-l-z-l (to shake). Form II passive: 'they were shaken violently'. Past passive third plural. They were SHAKEN with trials - fear, doubt, intense pressure!
'Until' - shows the EXTENT of the shaking. How much were they shaken? UNTIL...
From q-w-l (to say). Present tense (with narrative past meaning). Third singular: 'he says/said'. Until when?
'The Messenger' in nominative. The Prophet himself! Even THE MESSENGER was so tested that he said...
'And those who' - adds the believers with him.
Form IV past: 'they believed'. The believers WITH the Messenger also cried out...
'Maʿa' (with) + 'hu' (him). WITH the Messenger - together they were tested and cried out...
'When?' - question word. In their extreme trial, they asked: WHEN?
'Help' or 'victory' from n-ṣ-r (to help/support). In construct form: help OF...
Allah in genitive. Complete question: 'When will ALLAH'S HELP come?' This shows how severe their trial was - even the Messenger asked when relief would come!
'Alā' - calls attention, means 'Indeed!' or 'Behold!' or 'Know that'. Draws attention to important truth...
'Indeed' or 'verily' - adds emphasis to what follows. INDEED...
Same word 'help', now in accusative (after 'inna'). The help OF...
Allah in genitive. 'Allah's help' - complete phrase. INDEED Allah's help...
'Near' or 'close'. From q-r-b (to be near). Nominative with tanwīn. INDEED Allah's help is NEAR! Beautiful ending: Though trials are severe, Allah's help is always NEAR - never abandon hope!

verses.arabic: يَسْـَٔلُونَكَ مَاذَا يُنفِقُونَ ۖ قُلْ مَآ أَنفَقْتُم مِّنْ خَيْرٍ فَلِلْوَٰلِدَيْنِ وَٱلْأَقْرَبِينَ وَٱلْيَتَـٰمَىٰ وَٱلْمَسَـٰكِينِ وَٱبْنِ ٱلسَّبِيلِ ۗ وَمَا تَفْعَلُوا۟ مِنْ خَيْرٍ فَإِنَّ ٱللَّهَ بِهِۦ عَلِيمٌ
verses.transliteration: Yas'alūnaka mādhā yunfiqūna qul mā anfaqtum min khayrin fa-lil-wālidayni wal-aqrabīna wal-yatāmā wal-masākīni wabni s-sabīli wa-mā tafʿalū min khayrin fa-inna llāha bihi ʿalīmun
verses.translation: They ask you what they should donate. Say: 'Whatever donations you give are for parents, relatives, orphans, the poor, and needy travellers. Whatever good you do is certainly well known to Allah.'

grammar.practical: From s-'-l (to ask). Present yas'alūna + ka (you). Third plural ask + you. 'They ask YOU (O Prophet)' - companions asking for guidance.
'Mā' (what) + 'dhā' (that/this) = 'what' or 'what is it that'. Double question: WHAT should they spend?
From n-f-q (to spend). Form IV. Third plural present: 'they spend'. What should they SPEND (in charity)?
From q-w-l (to say). Imperative singular: 'Say!' Command to the Prophet to answer.
'What' or 'whatever' - conditional/general meaning. WHATEVER you spend...
Form IV from n-f-q. Second plural past: 'you spent'. WHATEVER you spend (of charity)...
'Of' or 'from' - partitive, showing type. Whatever you spend OF...
'Good' or 'wealth'. From kh-y-r (to be good). Genitive with tanwīn. 'Khayr' means both 'good' and 'wealth/property'. Whatever good/wealth you spend...

'Fa' (then/so) + 'li' (for) + 'al-wālidayn' (the parents). 'Wālidayn' is DUAL form of 'wālid' (parent). The '-ayni' ending shows dual genitive. First priority: FOR THE PARENTS (both mother and father)!
'And the closest ones' or 'close relatives'. From q-r-b (to be near). Plural: 'aqrabīn' = close relatives, family members. Second priority: close family!
'And the orphans'. Plural of 'yatīm' (orphan). From y-t-m (to be orphaned). Third priority: orphans who lost their parents!
'And the poor/needy'. Plural of 'miskīn' (poor person). From s-k-n. Fourth priority: the poor who have nothing!
'And ibn' (son). In construct form: 'ibn' (son) OF... But 'ibn as-sabīl' is an idiom meaning 'traveller'!

'The way' or 'path'. From s-b-l (path/way). Complete idiom: 'ibn as-sabīl' literally 'son of the path' = TRAVELLER/wayfarer. Fifth priority: stranded travellers! Beautiful priorities: family first, then vulnerable (orphans, poor, travelers)!
'And whatever' - general statement. WHATEVER you do...
From f-ʿ-l (to do). Second plural present: 'you do'. Whatever you DO (any good deed)...
Partitive 'of' - specifying type of action.
'Good'. Genitive with tanwīn. Whatever good you do (any good deed, especially charity)...
'Fa' (then/so) + 'inna' (indeed). Emphatic introduction: Then INDEED...
Allah in accusative (after 'inna'). Indeed ALLAH...
'Bi' (of/with) + 'hi' (it). OF IT or WITH IT - referring to the good you do.

'All-Knowing'. From ʿ-l-m (to know). Pattern 'faʿīl' shows intensity. Nominative with tanwīn. Allah is ALL-KNOWING about it! Beautiful assurance: Whatever good you do, even if people don't know, ALLAH KNOWS! He will reward you!

verses.arabic: كُتِبَ عَلَيْكُمُ ٱلْقِتَالُ وَهُوَ كُرْهٌۭ لَّكُمْ ۖ وَعَسَىٰٓ أَن تَكْرَهُوا۟ شَيْـًٔا وَهُوَ خَيْرٌۭ لَّكُمْ ۖ وَعَسَىٰٓ أَن تُحِبُّوا۟ شَيْـًٔا وَهُوَ شَرٌّۭ لَّكُمْ ۗ وَٱللَّهُ يَعْلَمُ وَأَنتُمْ لَا تَعْلَمُونَ
verses.transliteration: Kutiba ʿalaykumu l-qitālu wa-huwa kurhun lakum wa-ʿasā an takrahū shay'an wa-huwa khayrun lakum wa-ʿasā an tuḥibbū shay'an wa-huwa sharrun lakum wa-llāhu yaʿlamu wa-antum lā taʿlamūn
verses.translation: Fighting has been made obligatory upon you believers, though you dislike it. Perhaps you dislike something which is good for you and like something which is bad for you. Allah knows and you do not know.

words.translation: it has been written / prescribed / made obligatory

grammar.practical: From k-t-b (to write). Passive: 'it was written/prescribed'. In Islamic context, means 'made obligatory/legislated'. Passive shows it's Allah's decree.
'ʿAlā' (upon/on) + 'kum' (you plural). UPON YOU (Muslims) - prescribed for you.
'The fighting' or 'combat'. From q-t-l (to fight/kill). Nominative subject. Fighting in Allah's cause has been prescribed.
'And/while it' - pronoun referring to fighting. Though fighting is prescribed, it (fighting)...
'Disliked' or 'hated'. From k-r-h (to dislike). Nominative with tanwīn. It's DISLIKED - naturally people don't like fighting!
'La' (for/to) + 'kum' (you). FOR YOU - you dislike it. Natural human response!
'And perhaps' or 'it may be'. 'ʿAsā' is a special verb meaning 'perhaps/maybe' expressing possibility and hope.
'That' - introduces the clause of what 'perhaps' applies to.
From k-r-h (to dislike). Second plural subjunctive: 'you dislike'. Perhaps you dislike...
'Something' or 'a thing'. Accusative with tanwīn. Perhaps you dislike SOMETHING (general - anything)...
'And it' or 'while it' - referring to that 'something'. While it (that thing you dislike)...
'Good' or 'better'. From kh-y-r (to be good). Nominative with tanwīn. It's actually GOOD for you!
'For you'. That thing you dislike is actually GOOD FOR YOU!
Same word: 'And perhaps' - now the opposite case.
'That' - introduces second possibility.
From ḥ-b-b (to love). Second plural subjunctive: 'you love'. Perhaps you LOVE something...
Same word: 'something'. Perhaps you love SOMETHING...
'And it' - that thing you love...
'Evil' or 'bad' or 'harmful'. Opposite of 'khayr'. Nominative with tanwīn. It's actually BAD for you!
'For you'. That thing you love is actually BAD FOR YOU! Profound wisdom: our desires can deceive us!
Allah as subject. And ALLAH (knows better than you)...
From ʿ-l-m (to know). Third singular present: 'He knows'. Allah KNOWS (what's truly good for you)...
'And you' - plural pronoun. Contrast: Allah knows, but YOU...
Negation particle 'not'. You do NOT...
From ʿ-l-m. Second plural present: 'you know'. You do NOT KNOW! Beautiful wisdom: Allah KNOWS what's best, we DON'T. Trust His decree even if you dislike it - it's for your good!

verses.arabic: يَسْـَٔلُونَكَ عَنِ ٱلشَّهْرِ ٱلْحَرَامِ قِتَالٍۢ فِيهِ ۖ قُلْ قِتَالٌۭ فِيهِ كَبِيرٌۭ ۖ وَصَدٌّ عَن سَبِيلِ ٱللَّهِ وَكُفْرٌۢ بِهِۦ وَٱلْمَسْجِدِ ٱلْحَرَامِ وَإِخْرَاجُ أَهْلِهِۦ مِنْهُ أَكْبَرُ عِندَ ٱللَّهِ ۚ وَٱلْفِتْنَةُ أَكْبَرُ مِنَ ٱلْقَتْلِ
verses.transliteration: Yas'alūnaka ʿani sh-shahri l-ḥarāmi qitālin fīhi qul qitālun fīhi kabīrun wa-ṣaddun ʿan sabīli llāhi wa-kufrun bihi wal-masjidi l-ḥarāmi wa-ikhrāju ahlihi minhu akbaru ʿinda llāhi wal-fitnatu akbaru mina l-qatli
verses.translation: They ask you about fighting in the sacred months. Say: 'Fighting during these months is a great sin. But hindering others from the Path of Allah, rejecting Him, and expelling the worshippers from the Sacred Mosque is greater in the sight of Allah.'

grammar.practical: They ask you (O Prophet) - seeking guidance about a controversial issue.
'About' or 'concerning' - introduces the topic they're asking about.
'The month' in genitive (after 'ʿan'). From sh-h-r. Which month? Specified next...
'The sacred' or 'prohibited'. From ḥ-r-m (to be sacred/forbidden). Describes the month: the SACRED month (when fighting was traditionally prohibited in Arabia).
'Fighting' in genitive with tanwīn. They ask about FIGHTING (specifically) in the sacred month. This was a controversial early Islamic issue.
'In it' - in the sacred month. Is fighting IN IT allowed?
Command to Prophet: 'Say!' Here's the answer...
'Fighting' in nominative with tanwīn. Fighting (as subject)...
'In it' - in the sacred month. Fighting in it...
'Great' or 'major'. From k-b-r (to be great/big). Nominative with tanwīn. Fighting in the sacred month is a GREAT (sin) - it's serious!
'And blocking' or 'hindering'. From ṣ-d-d (to obstruct). Nominative with tanwīn. But BLOCKING (is even worse)...
'From' or 'away from' - hindering people FROM...
'The path' or 'way'. In construct form: path OF...
Allah in genitive. Complete phrase: 'hindering from Allah's path' - preventing people from Islam! This is WORSE than fighting in sacred month!
'And disbelief' or 'rejection'. From k-f-r. Nominative with tanwīn. And DISBELIEF in Allah...
'In Him' - disbelief IN ALLAH. Worse than fighting in sacred month!
'And the mosque' in genitive. From s-j-d (to prostrate). 'Masjid' = place of prostration. Which mosque? The sacred one...
